Comment: Completely destroyed is, unfortunately, a big exaggeration. Trump has shown a 4% drop in the polls since his inauguration. That’s it. In exchange we’ve had a massive wealth shift, untold damage to the US’s reputation and relationships with other countries, created an atmosphere of fear and uncertainty with ICE detaining innocent people indefinitely and shipping people off to a different country’s prison, and huge rise in inflation.   Was it really worth the 4% that was likely going to go down anyways?  Edit: ah, not to mention the US’s already dicey relationship with what is now definitively the strongest nation on earth will likely take generations to recover, if at all, which is a huge trading loss. We’ve alienated anyone who might be willing to make up for the loss in rare earth minerals like Canada or Greenland. Doge has made so many government cuts and gained access to the Treasury, dealing huge damage. LGBTQ+ and minority protections have gone out the window. The more I think the more I can come up with. All for 4% far ahead of any voting consequences.

Comment: From Hogg's perspective, guns are really good at ending multiple people in short order. In about 200 years, no gun has ever been used in America for any purpose besides target practice, hunting and ending small groups of people, mainly individual American citizens.  What does *American Hitler pulling people off the streets* have to do with owning a gun?  A: Absolutely nothing. Whatever you're alluding to, it's a non-starter.  Here's why: Andrew Jackson would randomly challenge his political opponents to gun duels while indigenous people marched in the Trail of Tears, which he executed in violation of the Supreme Court. What good did it do then, before the US had one of the most powerful, most well-funded militaries in the world, serving at the pleasure of the Commander-in-Chief? The one who won two pivotal elections by a free-voting public? In a country where Police services buy surplus military equipment including *APCs*?  They're creating an "autism" (i.e. general medical status) registry, they're jailing American-born citizens, they're ignoring the court they stacked and still can't win against, they're sending notices to leave the country to American lawyers *by accident*, and they are kicking out the Associated Press for using the word "Mexico" while inviting the least informed podcaster they could find to the press pool while suing historically trusted news institutions into compliance. They're punishing schools for not teaching to the President's standards, revising the history pages, and they're fucking up your economy, possibly forever and certainly for millennials and younger, including Hogg. Even third-rail politics, like social security, are getting attacked. And it's happening all at once.  The Republican Party learned fifteen years ago that change happens in the local races and through raising new leaders to understand the game. They understand that change, seasoned with fear-based manipulation, happens through the system.  But hey, at least you can own a gun.
Author: CitySeekerTron

Comment: My point is that power-yielding old-guard Democrats are wrong and Pelosi is wrong when that's the entire depth of reason she can offer for undermining the next generation of Democrat leadership. One product of this failed leadership was Schumer's decision to grant the Trump administration an unquestioned pass on the budget.    Hogg is passionate and is attempting to take the reigns in order to spur leadership change. And he's right - the Democrats are age-heavy and failing to prepare new leaders, and have lost votes because reps have died in office. I've criticized the Dems as a dying party while also describing conservatism as a dying political idea. I think Sanders recognizes this - he's on the road with AOC for a reason - but largely the only way for the party to survive is if there are leaders, and if the current leadership won't handle this, then the options for the younger generation is to let it die or to take it up themselves.
Author: CitySeekerTron

Comment: I don't know if you've noticed, but people are already winding up in jail, fighting to establish [their citizenship in court](https://thehill.com/homenews/state-watch/5255137-us-citizen-held-by-ice-despite-judge-seeing-birth-certificate/). And about a third of the US is cheering it on. The current administration is arguing that it would take too long to deal with all court cases for policies it's choosing to implement, and based on a scheduling conflict, they're hoping to convince SCOTUS to pretend that due process doesn't exist (and at least one has openly invited them to challenge past due process rulings).  The only fight you have a chance at winning is in the ballot box, and they're currently busy trying to make that ground untouchable because they're afraid of it. They understand that it's the only viable tool Americans have to equalize the battlefield, and that's why they're so keen to undermine it. No matter how much the distrust it, they know that it's the most legitimate way to unequivocally demonstrate who has the claim to lead.  Take your fight to the polls. Treat it like it's your duty as an American. If you want to serve your country and you believe in your mission, run for office and primary a do-nothing incumbent, debating like hell. Do battle at the box.
Author: CitySeekerTron

Comment: Conservatism is dead because there's nothing left for it to try and conserve. It's no longer about old traditions, and it's not about maintaining power structures. It's now about growing and deepening those power structures.  Traditionally, conservatism used to be about maintaining the status quo and tamping change. Today, where conservatism once walked, right-wing revolutionaries are running: people who want to change everything radically. Yes, there are elements of what could be conservatism within their ranks, but it's mainly for branding. The Democratic Party as it exists today is what might be characterized as centrist conservative, while the "party of limited government" is attempting to legislate social behavior and healthcare from the executive from a further right, authoritarian perspective.  I fully expect that there are conservatives who won't vote for Trump and the like, and I also expect that there are people who vote for the current-day GOP but will deny that Trump's doing shit in plain sight because they either don't think it would be permitted ("Nobody would actually let him do those things!") or because they think he's trolling the left ("He's just saying this stuff for attention"). They're politically homeless and don't know it.  All I can say to lefties is: vote like your country depends on it. If you stand with the idea of serving your country, then serve it when the locals come up just as fervently as the most committed American votes in the presidential election. And if you feel politically homeless, whether you identify as a conservative, liberal, or lefty, get your ass to the primaries and rebuild that home for yourself.  And if your party is making it difficult to engage in those events, figure out why.
Author: CitySeekerTron

Comment: Well the thing there is gun show sales are sales between two private individuals inside a state, and the federal government has no authority to control commerce inside a state.  So right off the bat trying to regulate that at the federal level is going to take you to the Supreme Court arguing the authority of the commerce clause and good luck doing that with this court.  If that’s something you want to focus on it really has to be at the state level and states are all over the place on how strict they are about sales between residents inside the state. In PA I can sell one of my AR15s to anyone who’s proven to me they’re over 18 and a PA resident, pretty loosey goosey, handguns have to done through a FFL which includes a background check just like if you were buying a new gun.   And the democrats ban gun narrative works because they’ve tried to do it every chance they’ve had. That’s a feeling built up over years and does not go away at the snap of a finger.
